title: Alabama Beef Systems Videos: How to Collect a Hay Sample

tasks.task: Collecting and analyzing hay samples for nutritional value
subtasks: Borrowing a forage probe from a county extension office
Using an electric drill to operate the forage probe
Collecting 15-20 core samples from individual bales within each lot
Inserting the probe into bales at a 90-degree angle for round bales (curved side, center for square bales)
Reversing drill direction to remove the probe
Detaching the probe from the drill and emptying into a mixing bucket
Thoroughly mixing samples in the bucket
Removing a sub-sample (about half of one quart) from the bucket
Using clean, labelable sample bags to place the sub-sample
Submitting both the sample and form to a certified forage testing laboratory
Planning sample submission two to three weeks prior to needed results
Defining a "lot" as hay from the same field and conditions (e.g., each cutting)
Consulting local extension agents for assistance

tasks.task: Preparing and utilizing results for feed management
subtasks: Reviewing the nutritional value report upon receipt
Using report to develop a supplementation plan
Working with local experts to complete sample submission and interpretation
